captions.text:
Good morning John. This week I flew in a tiny
plane to New York City where there were many

weird and fancy things. Here are some of them:
White asparagus, which was fed to me at definitely

the best restaurant I have ever been to. At
least the most expensive. White asparagus

is just asparagus that has never seen light,
and thus has a milder flavor and is not at

all green. This is weird for two reasons:
One: I feel like I have robbed asparagus of

reaching its full potential. And two: Because
who figured that out?

My hotel room had a mirror lens that I rather
enjoyed...
Ahhhhhhh. Errrweeeawagrrawahhherahhh.

Here's a tip, kids, when your umbrella breaks
in New York City, just throw it on the ground!

This urinal had ice in it. Why? I don't know.
I don't know! Pretty cool of the City of New

York to put this permanent installation of
TFiOS clouds in Central Park. I mean that

is just... That is just real nice. And finally
here are some tiny chairs that cost MCUH MORE

than normal sized chairs. And here is Time
Square, and what is that? That is just an

advertisement for the movie that they are
making out of my brother's book. The real

reason why I was in New York, and yes it was
great; I wish I could have seen more weird

stuff, but that is not why I was there. I
was there to see the premiere of The Fault

in Our Stars. The first time I had seen the
movie, and also to walk down the red carpet.

Which was cool, and lots of people took pictures
of me, but maybe just 'cause I asked them

to. Everybody take lots of pictures, I want
lots of flashes. Yeah, yeah. I say that because

none of them published any of the pictures
of me and my wife, which is too bad. But,

good news, my mom took a bunch too. And also
did you see how pretty my wife is? So pretty.

Katherine: "I feel like there is a bead of
sweat rolling down my back headed for my butt
crack."

And then I watched a movie, and I can't show
that to you 'cause copyright. Also, that would

be a really long YouTube video. And I am having
a hard time figuring out what to say about

it because it was super surreal. So here's--
we're just going to intellectualize... hyper-intellectualize

'cause that is what I am good at. This is
the book that I finished while I was in New

York. The Shades of Milk and Honey is like
Jane Austen with magic in it. One of the big

questions that books asks is are beautiful
things more or less beautiful if you understand

all of the hidden systems that go into the
creation of the beautiful thing? And as I

walked around New York, I kept seeing examples
of hidden systems on display. Like the escalator

at the Uniqlo had a window in the side so
that you can see how the escalator worked

on the inside. In the Museum of Modern Art
Design store, which one can assume has pretty

good tastes, was just full of examples of
this.

I think for a long time the trend has been
to hide the complexity. To hide the systems

in favor of this illusion of effortless perfection.
Hide the technology inside of the beautiful

box, right? So turn all entertainment into
a magic show. Construct the celebrity as this

perfect embodiment of cool. But since we started
here on Vlogbrothers, we have kind of been

doing the opposite. That is the whole point!
This is my real office. I am not wearing makeup.

We make T-shirts with a local printer; here
is how the process works. John's book is being

turned into a movie. Here's some videos of
the cast and crew on set. Here's how John

fells about it, and here's how I feel about
it. Right now how I am feeling is, I'll be

honest, overwhelmed. I'm afraid that we are
missing opportunities. I'm afraid that every

time that I talk to the New Yorker or The
Wall Street Journal that I am just going to

come off without the ability to say things
that make any sense. And I'm worried about

all of the external attention. But there is
one thing that I am not worried about. I am

not worried that people won't like the movie
or that the movie is bad because it's not.

It's great, and people are going to love it.
And yeah, I cried. I cried a bunch of times,

but not 'cause it subtracted from me. But,
because it added to me. It opened up the mysteries

of life, and love, and hurt for examination
and for understanding. And I think that that's

something that the world needs more of. John,
I'm proud of you! Everybody, go see the movie

whenever it comes out in your country on the
day that it comes out in your country! John,
I'll see you on Tuesday.

An advertisement for the book-i-dabawheebakalawhooaha.
Ahhhhhhhhhhh.

comments.author: Kema Summers

comments.text:
i think that what your looking for is a description? Idk, but here you go.

Vlogbrothers is a channel created by John and Hank Green (brothers) in 2007 
who saw a potential for a great community in youtube. The content at first 
consisted of them doing and saying whatever they want, but converted to a 
pre-teen friendly place (even though most subscribers are from ages 15 to 
30). They made rule's for the time of the video (Four minutes and one 
second for non-informational content) and if one didn't upload on their day 
(John is Tuesday and Hank is Friday) they could be punished. EXAMPLE: 
Waxing chin hair; spending 15 hours in target.

As the community grew, the fans of vlogbrothers started calling themselves 
"Nerdfighters", a term John misread on a video game in an airport. The 
community is now referred to as Nerdfighteria. Nerdfighteria has raised 
millions of dollars for multiple charities, and has a goal to decrease 
world suck. The term DFTBA (Don't forget to be awesome) is also used to 
signify that you are part of the community, and is told to others to either 
brighten their spirits or as a snappy comeback. 

John green is an author who has written The Fault in our Stars (TFIOS), 
Paper Towns,Will Grayson Will Grayson, Looking for Alaska (my personal 
favorite) and an Abundance of Katherine's. He has won a few awards and has 
been #1 on the best seller list, eventually getting his latest book The 
Fault in our Stars made into a movie this past June only two years after it 
was written. Nerdfighteria is also looking forward to Looking for Alaska 
and Paper Towns being made into a movie.

Hank Green is a musician. He rights funny and educational songs that every 
nerdfighter adores no matter the tempo. After he wrote a song about Harry 
Potter the channel gained more popularity, and is now at 2,000,000+ 
subscribers.

comments.text:
Why did Gus have to die I bought the movie and book and I almost finished 
the book but I loved Gus so much! At the beginning I was like ok I saw the 
trailer for TFIOS and I was like I'm reading the book and I was like Hazel 
and Gus are gunna b together 4ever and then Gus died and I cried for 3 days 
and my mom was like why are you crying and I'm like Gus died! And she like 
who is Gus and I told her from TFIOS and shes like its just a book and Im 
like you read it and about a week later she started crying and then I saw 
the movie and cried harder! But really WHY Gus!?! But his death really made 
the book realistic cuz most books are just basic 2 people fall in love and 
like happily ever after this book doesn't end like that it has a twist and 
it made it realistic and you can relate unlike cheesy romance books or 
movies, I love John Green! And I watched the movie with my friends btw we 
had to see a councilor to get over Gus's death and yes thats how much I 
loved him its just that once I read a book I become attached and begin to 
know and love the character and seeing Gus die is like seeing my boyfriend 
die so I really could relate. I love the book sooo much I'm reading it for 
the 4th time!﻿

comments.text:
The ice in the urinal is there because places like bars and restaurants 
produce tons of ice, and when a customer leaves unmelted ice in their 
glasses, the unmelted ice has to go SOMEWHERE to melt!

They place the buckets of ice in the urinals to ensure it melts faster 
because ice in air, vs ice in warmer water = ice in warmer water melts 
faster than ice in air, because of the density of the elements!

Air being lighter than water, has a lower heat mass than water.

And leaving the ice to sit out and melt in hot air instead would equal 
mountains of ice.. and no one wants that, as winter in Chicago is long 
enough!!(or wherever you are...)

You're welcome. :D﻿

comments.text:
Tiny furniture!  I went to a store to inquire as to how much these cost, 
several years ago, for a gift for my girlfriend.  These are classic 
furniture milestones, and I too was horrified that they cost much more than 
what I could justify for real furniture.  Mind you, they cost nowhere near 
as much as the *real* versions of the furniture of which they are 
miniatures.  The final insult to the injury was that the store was called 
"Design Within Reach".  Within reach of whom, exactly?  The name is an 
absolute insult to anyone who understands what those three words actually 
mean when you actually put them together.﻿
comments.author: delusionnnnn

comments.text:
The Fault in Our Stars is one of those books that made me feel sorry for 
people who don't read, because they are missing out on one of life's 
greatest pleasures.  I'm relieved to say that the movie is also great, and 
so TFiOS has not yet become one of those wonderful books that are made into 
terrible movies (e.g. The Great Gatsby and those abominations called The 
Hobbit movies even though they have virtually nothing to do with The 
Hobbit).﻿
